http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Wikitext_examples


You can ''italicize text'' by putting 2 apostrophes on each side.

3 apostrophes will bold '''the text'''.

5 apostrophes will bold and italicize '''''the text'''''.

(Using 4 apostrophes doesn't do anything special --there are just ' '''left over ones'''' that are included as part of the text.)


A single newline generally has n<tt>o effect on the layout. Thes</tt>e can be used to separate sen''tences within a paragraph. Some ed'''itors find tha''t this aids editing a'''nd improves the ''diff'' function (used internally to compare different versions of a page).

But an empty line starts a new paragraph.


You can break lineswithout a new paragraph.Please use this sparingly.

Please do not start a link or ''italics'' or '''bold''' on one line and close it on the next.


 Put text in a typewriter font. The same font is generally used for computer code.
 Strike out or underline text, or write it in small caps. 

<div style="text-align:center;">Centered text</div>

* Please note the American spelling of "center". 

Section headings

''Headings'' organize your writing into sections. The Wiki software can automatically generate a [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Table_of_contents table of contents] from them.

'''Subsection'''

Using more "equals" (=) signs creates a subsection.

'''A smaller subsection'''

Don't skip levels, like from two to four equals signs.

Start with 2 equals signs not 1 because 1 creates H1 tags which should be reserved for page title.


= Level1 =

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

== Level2 ==

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

== Level2 ==

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

=== Level3 ===

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

=== Level3 ===

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

==== Level4 ====

'''OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

=== Level3 ===

'''Left: OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

== Level2 ==

'''Justified: OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''

=== Level3 ===

<div style="text-align:center;">'''Center: OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''</div>

= Level1 =

<div style="text-align:right;">'''Right: OpenOffice.org''' is ''a [http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html multiplatfor][http://www.openoffice.org/dev_docs/source/sys_reqs.html m] and''' [http://www.openoffice.org/project/projects/native-lang.html multilingual] [http://www.openoffice.org/product/index.html office suite] and''''' an [http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.php open-source] project.'' '''Compatible''' with all '''''other''''' '''''major''''' ''office'' ''suites'', the product is free to download, use, and distribute. To help build the community,''''' [http://contributing.openoffice.org/index.html join us]. '''''</div>


Test


* ''Unordered [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:List lists] are easy to do: 
** Start every line with a star. 
*** More stars indicate a deeper level. Previous item continues. 
** A newline 
* in a list 

marks the end of the list.

* Of course you can start again. 

# ''Numbered lists'' are: 
## Very organized 
## Easy to follow 

A newline marks the end of the list.

# New numbering starts with 1. 

Here's a ''definition list'':

# Word<br/> Definition of the word 
# A longer phrase needing definition 
# Phrase defined 
# A word
# Which has a definition 
# Also a second one 
# And even a third 

Begin with a semicolon. One item per line; a newline can appear before the colon, but using a space before the colon improves parsing.


You can even do mixed lists 

# and nest them 
# inside each other 
#* or break linesin lists. definition lists <br/> can be <br/> nested<br/> too 

You can even do mixed lists 

# and nest them 
# inside each other 
#* or break linesin lists. definition lists <br/> can be <br/> nested<br/> too
# ee
# ee
#* eee
#* eeee
#** eeeee
#** eeee
#* kjjkjk
# klklklkl

# aslasasl
# salkklas
## slsdlsdl
## dslksdlksdkl
## sdklsdlksd
### dsklsdlksdkl
### sdklsdlksd
#### kdsklsdklsd
##### sdklsdklsdkl
##### sdklsdlksd
#### cdkldfkldf
## fdkldflkdfkl
## dkldflkdf
## fdkldfkldf
# dfjkdfjkdf
# dfjkdfjk
# 

You can add footnotes to sentences using the ''ref'' tag -- this is especially good for citing a source.

There are over six billion people in the world.<ref name="ftn1"># [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Wikitext_examples#_ref-0 ↑] CIA World Factbook, 2006. 

For details, see [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Footnotes Wikipedia:Footnotes] and [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Footnotes Help:Footnotes].</ref>


 Here's a link to a page named [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position Official position]. You can even say [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position official positions] and the link will show<ref name="ftn2"> More information</ref> up correctly. 

 You can put formatting around a link. Example: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. 

 The ''first letter'' of articles is automatically capitalized, so [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia wikipedia] goes to the same place as [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. Capitalization matters after the first letter. 

 [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_weather_in_London&action=edit The weather in London] is a page that doesn't exist yet. You could create it by clicking on the link. 

You can link to a page section by its title:

* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_by_country&action=edit List of cities by country#Morocco]. 

If multiple sections have the same title, add a number. [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Wikitext_examples#Example_section_3 #Example section 3] goes to the third section named "Example section".


You can make a link point to a different place with a [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Piped_link piped link]. Put the link target first, then the pipe character "|", then the link text.

* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Link About Links] 
* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_by_country&action=edit Cities in Morocco] 

Or you can use the "pipe trick" so that text in parentheses or text after a comma does not appear.

* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=Spinning_%28textiles%29&action=edit Spinning] 
* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=Boston%2C_Massachusetts&action=edit Boston] 

You can make an external link just by typing a URL: [http://www.nupedia.com/ http://www.nupedia.com]

You can give it a title: [http://www.nupedia.com/ Nupedia]

Or leave the title blank: [http://www.nupedia.com/ [1]]


 Linking to an e-mail address works the same way: [mailto:someone@example.com mailto:someone@example.com] or [mailto:someone@example.com someone] 

 You can [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Redirect redirect] the user to another page. 

[http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Category Category links] do not show up in line but instead at page bottom ''and cause the page to be'' listed in the category.

Add an extra colon to ''link'' to a category in line without causing the page to be listed in the category: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:English_documentation Category:English documentation]


The Wiki reformats linked dates to match the reader's date preferences. These three dates will show up the same if you choose a format in your [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:Preferences Preferences]:

* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=1969&action=edit 1969]-[http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=July_20&action=edit 07-20] 
* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=July_20&action=edit July 20], [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=1969&action=edit 1969] 
* [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=July_20&action=edit 20 July] [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=1969&action=edit 1969] 

A picture, including alternate text:

[[Image:Wiki.png]]

You can put the image in a frame with a caption:


<div style="text-align:right;">[[Image:Wiki.png]]</div>

<div style="text-align:right;">This Wiki's logo</div>


 [[Image:Wiki.png|thumb|<div style="text-align:center;"></div> <div style="text-align:center;">This Wiki's logo</div> A link to Wikipedia's page for the image: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Image:Wiki.png Image:Wiki.png] Or a link directly to the image itself: [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/meta/b/bc/Wiki.png Media:Wiki.png]]]

A link to Wikipedia's page for the image: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Image:Wiki.png Image:Wiki.png]

Or a link directly to the image itself: [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/meta/b/bc/Wiki.png Media:Wiki.png]


 Use '''media:''' links to link directly to sounds or videos: [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/meta/9/97/Sg_mrob.ogg A sound file] 

 Here's a link to a page named [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position Official position]. You can even say [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position official positions] and the link will show<ref name="ftn3"> More information</ref> up correctly. 

 You can put formatting around a link. Example: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. 

 The ''first letter'' of articles is automatically capitalized, so [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia wikipedia] goes to the same place as [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. Capitalization matters after the first letter. 

 [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_weather_in_London&action=edit The weather in London] is a page that doesn't exist yet. You could create it by clicking on the link. Here's a link to a page named [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position Official position]. You can even say [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position official positions] and the link will show<ref name="ftn4"> More information</ref> up correctly. 

 You can put formatting around a link. Example: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. 

 The ''first letter'' of articles is automatically capitalized, so [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia wikipedia] goes to the same place as [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. Capitalization matters after the first letter. 

 [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_weather_in_London&action=edit The weather in London] is a page that doesn't exist yet. You could create it by clicking on the link. Here's a link to a page named [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position Official position]. You can even say [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Official_position official positions] and the link will show<ref name="ftn5"> More information</ref> up correctly. 

 You can put formatting around a link. Example: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. 

 The ''first letter'' of articles is automatically capitalized, so [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia wikipedia] goes to the same place as [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia Wikipedia]. Capitalization matters after the first letter. 

 [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_weather_in_London&action=edit The weather in London] is a page that doesn't exist yet. You could create it by clicking on the link.
